section.title: Problem
section.para: You need to find professional fonts, preferebly released under an open source license which can be used for print or Web formats.

section.title: Solution
section.para: There are some very good fonts which can be used freely. Most fonts are even released under the Open Font License or other license. The following list is a small overview which is by no means complete (use also your favorite search enginge):

listitem.para: SILSummer Institute of Linguistics is a nonprofit organization for sustainable language development. On part is to support the use of non-Roman and complex scripts in language development. SIL creates the Charis SIL, Doulos SIL, Gentium, Andika, and other typefaces. All fonts are released under the
Google Web Fonts is a huge collection of open source fonts. They can be freely incorporated into your Web sites using CSS or can be downloaded and embedded in PDF.
The TeTeX distribution and CTANComprehensive TeX Archive Network contains also some high quality fonts, however, more aimed at the print business and not for the Web.

section.title: Discussion
section.para: Before you use a font, check the following list:

formalpara.title: Amount of Glyphs
formalpara.para: Does your font support all your languages? Although modern Unicode fonts support a wide range of glyphs they usually do not support every language.

formalpara.title: Missing Styles
formalpara.para: Some fonts are published in only one style, usually regular. Such fonts makes it more difficult to universally adopt them in different scenarios where more styles (bold, italic, or a combination) are needed.

formalpara.title: Font Format
formalpara.para: Modern fonts are usually Unicode fonts in OTFOpenType Font or TrueType format. Older fonts are mostly PostScript Type 1 fonts which have a limited amount of glphys (theoretically 256) and can not be used on the Web.
